channel.title: Bittorrent to Email
channel.description:
So I have a connection that peers with google. Which means that traffic to google is unmetered.
I'm thinking of getting a VPS that runs bittorrent. Splits the file into parts, encrypt them and then emails them to gmail. I then retrieve. Alternatively just upload and download with GmailFS.
So any advice on this kind of setup? What hosting is the cheapest but would let me get away with the high-bandwidth / CPU usage? Is Gmail going to rage at me?

item.title: Bittorrent to Email
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“BAsh, post:3, topic:333120”]Thats an idea. My inbox is 7GB+ so in terms of hard limits there is no advantage but google code might hide the large file size issue. That said I’m sure there are people who just use it like uppit so there might be stricter controls.

There still is the issue with the bittorrent side though. Any thoughts on hosting providers that let you torrent?[/quote]

If you remember the old server that mitb.moparisthebest.com used to be hosted on, which earlier used to host the forums that I rented from kib (veritynet). I used to run torrentflux on that and downloaded literally terabytes of data with it and he never noticed/cared. It was a dedicated server though.

Read full topic

item.title: Bittorrent to Email
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

[quote=“BAsh, post:3, topic:333120”]Thats an idea. My inbox is 7GB+ so in terms of hard limits there is no advantage but google code might hide the large file size issue. That said I’m sure there are people who just use it like uppit so there might be stricter controls.

There still is the issue with the bittorrent side though. Any thoughts on hosting providers that let you torrent?[/quote]

I read about that awhile ago. I don’t think any “let” you torrent. But you just do it, if they catch you then your service gets cancelled and no refund. Otherwise you will be fine. I don’t see why you want to go this route though unless you are as paranoid about bittorrent as I am.

Also, you could just write modify a open source bittorrent client, make it look like something its not, download the files with a weird extension that really isnt the write extension. Then encrypt them, then send them out. I really don’t see how they could find out this way. Really what im trying to say is make a program that runs that they can’t find and make sure they can’t read the files.

Read full topic

item.title: Bittorrent to Email
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

What about code.google.com and just syncing it to there? It might be easier and less noticeable.

Read full topic
